pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [4e77cfd60a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20722/commits/4e77cfd60a8e33244f53b741483ec9c64802362c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ biUnion_null`
`+ biUnion_volume`
`+ measurable_null_nullmeasurable`
`+ measurable_nullmeasurable`
`+ nullmeasurable_measurable_null`
`+ shift_nullmeasurable`
`+ shift_volume`
`+ union_volume_null`
`+ vI`
`+ vI_countable`
`+ vI_infinite`
`+ vRep`
`+ vRep_spec`
`+ vS`
`+ vS_vT_surj`
`+ vT`
`+ vitaliSet`
`+ vitaliSet'`
`+ vitaliSet_not_measurable`
`+ vitaliSet_not_nullmeasurable`
`+ vitaliSet_upper_bound`
`+ vitaliUnion`
`+ vitaliUnion_lower_bound`
`+ vitaliUnion_upper_bound`
`+ vitaliUnion_volume_range`
`+ vitaliUnion_volume_sum`
`+ vitali_pairwise_disjoint`
`+ volume_mono`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Question: as I update the PR, should I collapse my successive commits into a single commit, or keep them separate?  I'm keeping them separate for now, but I can also collapse them if that's the convention.

Indeed, different repositories have different conventions on this question. Adding separate comments is exactly right. When merging this pull request at the end, all commits are squashed into one (and the PR description is used to determine the final commit message).
Thanks for replying.   I've replied above why I don't want to make certain changes and asked for clarification on some other issues.  What's the next step?

I think it's going to be really hard to convince the reviewers to have 30-odd extra lines of code listing specific dependencies of your proof. First of all, you're not even making the formal guarantee that these are sufficient conditions for the theorem to hold (and if you did, you'd likely end up with a much uglier and unwieldy statement). And second, there's no guarantee someone else couldn't come to this file later on and add or switch out these dependencies.

The archive is meant as a showcase of good proofs, which doesn't always overlap with a good mathematical presentation. I really don't think we need to go over the basics of measure theory here.

Thanks for your pull request, and welcome to mathlib! I took a first look at your PR.
There are a number of places where your code can be written more compactly (i.e., doing the same thing, but being shorter). Such is completely normal for a first pull request. I have left some comments to get you started.

A number of comments occur several times: when addressing it once, please try to go over the file and fix all instances of it. If you're unsure, feel free to ask here (or on zulip)!

Thanks for your pull request, and welcome to mathlib! I took a first look at your PR.
There are a number of places where your code can be written more compactly (i.e., doing the same thing, but being shorter). Such is completely normal for a first pull request. I have left some comments to get you started.

A number of comments occur several times: when addressing it once, please try to go over the file and fix all instances of it. If you're unsure, feel free to ask here (or on zulip)!

Do you need this result in the final file? (It's fine if this was helpful during development, but we'd like to merge a polished version into mathlib.) In other words: I think it's better to simply delete this.

I prefer to enumerate explicitly all the measure theoretic results that are involved, because I want to make clear exactly which properties of measurability and the volume measure are used in the proof.  I have updated the comment to make this point.
Maybe this characterization can be part of the module docs instead? Listing results like this is quite nonconventional.
You can probably "inline" this lemma (i.e., replace every time you want to you `volume_mono h` by `OuterMeasureclass.measure_mono volume h`). Can you do so, please?
See my reply above.
A similar comment applies here. (Using dot notation, you can even write `h.nullMeasurableSet`.)
See my reply above.  I did change to the dot-notation.
Also inline this one, please.
See my reply above.

Using dot notation, you can write this more compactly as `h.exists_measurable_subset_ae_eq`.
Please also check further if you can use the same trick.
Fixed.

You can combine these lines into `exact ae_le_set.mp t.eq_s.symm.le`, in several steps:
- inline the last proof term into the "hole" (the `?_`) of the refine call
- refine without any holes can usually be replaced by `exact`

In fact, you can even combine the constructor call into one line: `exact measure_congr t_eq_s, t_eq_s.symm.le`
You can do similar transformations in the next lines: please do so.
Fixed, though I kept the "constructor".  The "exact (...., ...)" form you suggested does not work and, in my view, isn't any clearer than having the "constructor" and case split.
style: please put spaces around the `''`, i.e. write ` '' s`
Fixed
You can probably "inline" this (i.e. replace `hu` by its proof directly). Please do so, also for `hd`.
I'm not sure shorter is always clearer.  The explicit statement of the proposition makes the proof easier to read.

You can (usually) replace a proof `by exact something` by the proof term `something` directly. Please do so.
(Then, you'll be able to inline the `have`: if it's used only once, please do so. Also further below.)
Fixed.
You can write this in one line, as I remarked above. Please do so.
Fixed.
You can combine these two lines like `use t1 + t2, by simp`.
Not sure I understand your comment.  I tried "use t1 + t2, by simp" and it does not parse.
`rintro` allows introducing several variables at once: please combine these two lines.
Fixed.
Like below: please combine these two lines.
Not sure I understand your comment.  Please clarify.
I don't think this result is needed, since `t` is just the set given by `exists_measurable_subset_ae_eq` and the conclusions follow from the (I imagine more useful) `t =[] s` predicate.
Sorry, does your comment apply to the lemma measurable_null_nullmeasurable or the lemma nullmeasurable_measurable_null?
It applies to the latter, though I do agree with the other reviewer that the former shouldn't be duplicated here.

You can write this as
```suggestion
lemma shift_volume (s : Set ) (c : ) : volume (( + c) '' s) = volume s := by
```
Still, I don't think we need to have this theorem. It can just be inlined, or even replaced by a `simp` call.
Surely this can be generalized to any measure space?

I don't need the more general result.  As I stated in the comment at the beginning:

/-- We first enumerate all measure theoretic results that we will need.  We do so
because we want to make clear exactly which properties of measurability and the volume
measure are used in the proof of the non-measurability of the Vitali set. -/

Mathlib has interoperability as a core philosophy. More than once we've postponed much more important mathematical developments, simply because we couldn't find the appropriate high level generalization.

If this lemma is useful to you on reals, and it's not meaningfully more difficult to prove in general, then it's almost a bit rude not to prove it.
Why the duplication?
Sorry, what is being duplicated?
This is just a specific case of the lemma `measure_biUnion_null_iff` you list below. Or is this still within your category of lemmas you're duplicating deliberately?

a) This should have a more descriptive name, like `vitaliSetoid`.
b) This is just the quotient group `[0, 1] / `, can you use that in the proof instead? That should hopefully iron out a lot of the trivialities like these.
What about `VitaliType` or just `Vitali`?
This isn't really needed, you can just use `Quotient.mk_surjective` directly.
This is just `Quotient.out`.
This is just `Quotient.out_eq`.

```suggestion
def vitaliSet : Set  := Set.range vRep
```

It seems a bit more natural to write
```suggestion
def vI : Set  := (() :   ) '' Icc (-1 : ) 1
```
It should also have a more descriptive name. But I have a suspicion this isn't even needed.

Doesn't this work?
```suggestion
def vitaliUnion : Set  :=  i  Set.Icc (-1 : ) 1, vitaliSet' i
```
I'd suggest you inline `vitaliSet'` as well.

```suggestion
lemma volume_vitaliUnion_mem : volume vitaliUnion  Set.Icc 1 3 := by
```
This should follow more easily from [`Set.Icc_infinite`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Interval/Set/Infinite.html#Set.Icc_infinite).

```suggestion
lemma volume_vitaliUnion (hm : NullMeasurableSet vitaliSet volume) :
```
I think you can prove (and add to Mathlib) an auxiliary theorem for this: a sum ` i : I, x` for an infinite type `I` is either `0` or ``.

```suggestion
theorem not_nullMeasurableSet_vitaliSet :  NullMeasurableSet vitaliSet volume := by
```

```suggestion
theorem not_measurableSet_vitaliSet :  MeasurableSet vitaliSet :=
  fun hm  vitaliSet_not_nullmeasurable (measurable_nullmeasurable hm)
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Counterexamples): the Vitali set is non-measurable
